item.title: Python Blog Post
item.description: Let’s examine the diamonds dataset using both R and Python, thanks to the wonders of reticulate! diamonds library(reticulate) library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ ggplot2 3.3.3 ✓ purrr 0.3.4 ## ✓ tibble 3.0.4 ✓ dplyr 1.0.2 ## ✓ tidyr 1.1.2 ✓ stringr 1.4.0 ## ✓ readr 1.4.0 ✓ forcats 0.5.0 ## ── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ── ## x dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter() ## x dplyr::lag() masks stats::lag() df <- diamonds cut_counts <- df %>% group_by(cut) %>% count() import numpy as np total = np.

item.title: Project1
item.description: Project 1 Sahil Bolar ssb2747 Introduction This project contains two datasets from FiveThirtyEight with data on major, salary, employment, and other pertinent information about the job market. One dataset contains information on all college graduates, while the other contains information only on recent graduates. I am interested in seeing whether and to what extent the job market differs for recent graduates vs the overall workforce, controlling for major choice.

item.title: Project2
item.description: Project 2 Sahil Bolar, ssb2747 Introduction hate_crimes %>% glimpse ## Rows: 51 ## Columns: 13 ## $ state <chr> "Alabama", "Alaska", "Arizona", "Arkansas… ## $ state_abbrev <chr> "AL", "AK", "AZ", "AR", "CA", "CO", "CT",… ## $ median_house_inc <int> 42278, 67629, 49254, 44922, 60487, 60940,… ## $ share_unemp_seas <dbl> 0.060, 0.064, 0.063, 0.052, 0.059, 0.040,… ## $ share_pop_metro <dbl> 0.64, 0.63, 0.90, 0.69, 0.97, 0.80, 0.94,… ## $ share_pop_hs <dbl> 0.
